Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Chemtrade Bay Point Works is committed to being a responsible member of the community. Corporate policy dictates that facilities minimize the potential for adverse effects to the environment as well as to the health of employees and local citizens by operating plants safely. This commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented in the corporate policy and compliance procedures that are available to all employees. BPW stresses safe and environmentally sound operations in the employee training programs and in written materials available to employees.
Methods of minimizing or reusing wastes, in addition to using energy and materials wisely, are encouraged. BPW is committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner. We use accidental release prevention programs to make sure our processes are managed safely, as well as to comply with regulatory requirements such as OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM), USEPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Contra Costa County's Industrial Safety Ordinance (ISO). However, if a release were to occur, we have prepared our personnel and local emergency response groups to respond to accordingly.
The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
BPW produces high purity acids, etchants, and photoresist strippers for the semiconductor industry. Regulated substances managed on-site include anhydrous and aqueous ammonia, anhydrous hydrogen fluoride, and, hydrofluoric and hydrochloric acids.
Anhydrous ammonia and anhydrous hydrogen fluoride are used as feed stock in manufacturing processes. Anhydrous ammonia is used to manufacture ammonium fluoride. Anhydrous hydrogen fluoride is used to manufacture electronic grade hydrofluoric acid. Aqueous ammonia and hydrochloric acid are received, stored and distributed to customers.
The General Accidental Release Prevention Program
BPW has taken all the necessary step

s to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA and Title 19 of the State of California as well as the Contra Costa County Industrial Safety Ordinance. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the site.

Process Safety Information (PSI)
BPW maintains detailed records of safety information that describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. Examples include; Material Safety Data Sheets, piping and instrumentation diagrams, and, equipment specification sheets.
Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
BPW conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the covered processes are identified and effectively controlled. The HAZOP methodology is primarily used to carry out these analyses. Studies utilize an appropriate team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering, maintenance and process operations and are revalidated on a five year basis. Any findings related to the hazard analysis, where a response is required, are tracked to ensure resolution in a timely and appropriate manner.

Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within BPW's covered process, written operating procedures are maintained. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, and, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround. The information is reviewed annually and is readily accessible to operators processes.

Training
BPW has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating the processes are competent in the associated operating procedures and safe work practices. Refresher training is provided at least once every 3 years and more frequently as needed for required or updated process and safety topics.

Mechanical In

tegrity (MI)
BPW carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks includes, among others, pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, critical instruments, emergency shutdown systems, controls, compressors and pumps. Qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices are utilized to carry out appropriate maintenance. These personnel are also offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change (MOC)
Written procedures are in place at BPW to safely manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to safely work with the modification.

Prestartup Safety Review (PSSR)
PSSR related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted by appropriate personnel as a regular practice at BPW. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
BPW conducts audits of compliance systems for RMP requirements on a regular basis. These audits are carried out at least once every 3 years by a team of qualified personnel. Any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are tracked to ensure resolution in a timely and appropriate manner.

Incident Investigation
BPW promptly and carefully investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the rel

ease from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
BPW believes that Process Safety Management and accident prevention is a team effort. Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. BPW employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the accidental release prevention programs, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular. Safe job performance is required for all employees at the site.

Contractors
On occasion, BPW hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction and various other activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out. BPW has a policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes. Contractors are also required to inform BPW of any hazards they may introduce at the site. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur. Contractors, however, are never engaged to operate the BPW processes.

Five-year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases as defined by the RMP, CalARP or Contra Costa County Industrial Safety Ordinance programs from BPW within the last 5 years.

Emergency Response Plan (ERP)
BPW utilizes a written ERP to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, sheltering-in-place, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas. To ensure proper functioning, BPW emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent chang

es taking place that would require a modified emergency response. BPW also coordinates our plans and actions with local agencies which provide BPW with additional emergency response capability.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Studies associated with prevention program elements such as PHA's including external events analyses and seismic analyses, incident investigation, change management, and compliance audits are regularly conducted at BPW to verify designs and identify potential hazards. Recommendations may be developed as a result of these studies and as a result of equipment inspections, safety meetings, industry experience, technology improvements, and employee suggestions. Once formulated, recommendations are reviewed and corresponding action items are developed to implement appropriate recommendations. Communication of these action items or planned activities informs the public of measurable improvements for safety that are being continuously incorporated at the BPW facility. Additionally Chemtrade legacy plants are Responsible Care 14001 certified, it is Chemtrade's goal to have Bay Point Works work towards this goal as well.

Updates
BPW reviews and updates this RMP as follows:
¿ Within five years of its initial submission or most recent update whichever is later.
¿ No later than three years after a newly regulated substance is first listed by USEPA or CalEMA.
¿ No later than the date on which a new regulated substance is first present in an already covered process.
¿ No later than the date on which a regulated substance is first present above a threshold quantity in a new process.
¿ Within 6 months of a change that requires a revised PHA or hazard review.
¿ Within 6 months of a change that requires a revised offsite consequence analysis.
¿ Within 6 months of a change that alters the program level that applies to any covered process.
